prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: J1604_b7_12m
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2), HCO+(4-3), and continuum observation toward J1604.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Lower velocity resolution gives higher sensitivity that is important to detect the depleted gas in the cavity. However, lower resolution is not necessarily a good choice if there is a steep velocity gradient within the beam and the emission is not uniformly distributed over the velocity range. In addition, to explore the gas kinematics and its deviation from a Keplerian orbit, higher velocity resolution is essential. As a result, the velocity resolution is chosen in such a way that the Keplerian velocity is well resolved. To satisfy the conditions above, velocity resolution of ~ 0.2 km/s for CO (3-2) and HCO+ (4-3) line observations is selected so that the Keplerian motion within 100 AU is well resolved.

The purpose of this observation is to deeply see inside of the cavity associated with the 2MASS J1604. Our near-IR observation revealed the size of cavity of um-sized dust disk was 63 AU (0.43") in radius and CO(J=3-2) observation in Cycle 0 showed that the cavity radius of 31 AU (0.21") for the gas disk (Zhang et al. 2014). Therefore, we propose angular resolution of 0.2" so that beam size is sufficiently smaller than the cavity size. As a result of CO(J=3-2) ALMA cycle 0 observation, the gas extends to 4" (Zhang et al. 2014) and thus we concidered the largest angular scale for the source is 4". Note that typically dust component distributes more compact than the gas component does.

Our observation is composed of CO(J=3-2), HCO+(J=4-3), and continuum observations. CO(J=3-2) emission is detected by ALMA cycle0 and peak eission was 795 mJy/beam (Fig. 2, Zhang et al. 2014). Since we don't have HCO+(J=4-3) result for J1604, we assume flux density ratio between CO(J=3-2) and HCO+(J=4-3) of simillar object TW Hya, which is available in the science verification database, can be applicable. As a result, the ratio of HCO+(J=4-3) to CO(J=3-2) is 29/40. Considering the effect of different beam size, the expected flux density of HCO+(J=4-3) is approximately 69 mJy/beam (CO(J=3-2) emission is 95 mJy/beam). Since we try to detect diffused gas in the cavity in this observation, we aim for 15 sigma detection. Therefore, the desired sensitivity per pointing is 4.6 mJy.
For CO(J=3-2) and HCO+(J=4-3) lines, we select velocity resolution of 0.21 km/s, corresponding to 234.375 MHz in bandwidth. Since the velocity width of this target is approximately 2.2 km/s, velocity resolution of 0.21 km/s can well resolve Keplerian motion within 100 AU.
For continuum observation, 1.875 GHz was selected for bandwidth to maximize the sensitivity. Our observational setup will reach the sensitivity down to approximately 0.04 mJy/beam during the line observation when total bandwidth of 3.75 GHz (1.875 GHz x 2 spw) is used. This means that it is capable of detecting a typical disk around low-mass star with tremendously high signal-to-noise ratio. As a result, the expected disk structure can be safely detected if dust exists in the cavity.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UXTauA_b7_12m
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2), HCO+(4-3), and continuum observation toward UX Tau A.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Lower velocity resolution gives higher sensitivity that is important to detect the depleted gas in the cavity. However, lower resolution is not necessarily a good choice if there is a steep velocity gradient within the beam and the emission is not uniformly distributed over the velocity range. In addition, to explore the gas kinematics and its deviation from a Keplerian orbit, higher velocity resolution is essential. As a result, the velocity resolution is chosen in such a way that the Keplerian velocity is well resolved. To satisfy the conditions above, velocity resolution of ~ 0.2 km/s for CO (3-2) and HCO+ (4-3) line observations is selected so that the Keplerian motion within 100 AU is well resolved.

The purpose of this observation is to deeply see inside of the cavity associated with the UX Tau A. Our near-IR observation revealed the size of cavity of um-sized dust was 25 AU (0.18") in radius. Therefore, we propose angular resolution of 0.2" so that beam size is sufficiently smaller than the cavity size. As a result of NIR observation y Subaru Telescope, the disk extends to 2" (Tanii et al. 2012) and thus we concidered the largest angular scale for the source is 2". Note that typically dust component distributes more compact than the gas component does.

Our observation is composed of CO(J=3-2), HCO+(J=4-3), and continuum observations. CO(J=3-2) emission is detected by ALMA cycle0 and peak eission was 795 mJy/beam (Fig. 2, Zhang et al. 2014). Since we don't have HCO+(J=4-3) result for J1604, we assume flux density ratio between CO(J=3-2) and HCO+(J=4-3) of simillar object TW Hya, which is available in the science verification database, can be applicable. As a result, the ratio of HCO+(J=4-3) to CO(J=3-2) is 29/40. Considering the effect of different beam size, the expected flux density of HCO+(J=4-3) is approximately 69 mJy/beam (CO(J=3-2) emission is 95 mJy/beam). Since we try to detect diffused gas in the cavity in this observation, we aim for 15 sigma detection. Therefore, the desired sensitivity per pointing is 4.6 mJy.
For CO(J=3-2) and HCO+(J=4-3) lines, we select velocity resolution of 0.24 km/s, corresponding to 468.75 MHz in bandwidth. Since the velocity width of this target is approximately 2.2 km/s, velocity resolution of 0.24 km/s can well resolve Keplerian motion within 100 AU.
For continuum observation, 1.875 GHz was selected for bandwidth to maximize the sensitivity. Our observational setup will reach the sensitivity down to approximately 0.04 mJy/beam during the line observation when total bandwidth of 3.75 GHz (1.875 GHz x 2 spw) is used. This means that it is capable of detecting a typical disk around low-mass star with tremendously high signal-to-noise ratio. As a result, the expected disk structure can be safely detected if dust exists in the cavity.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: PDS 70_b7_12m
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO(3-2), HCO+(4-3), and continuum observation toward PDS 70.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Lower velocity resolution gives higher sensitivity that is important to detect the depleted gas in the cavity. However, lower resolution is not necessarily a good choice if there is a steep velocity gradient within the beam and the emission is not uniformly distributed over the velocity range. In addition, to explore the gas kinematics and its deviation from a Keplerian orbit, higher velocity resolution is essential. As a result, the velocity resolution is chosen in such a way that the Keplerian velocity is well resolved. To satisfy the conditions above, velocity resolution of ~ 0.2 km/s for CO (3-2) and HCO+ (4-3) line observations is selected so that the Keplerian motion within 100 AU is well resolved.

The purpose of this observation is to deeply see inside of the cavity associated with the PDS 70. Our near-IR observation revealed the size of cavity of um-sized dust was 70 AU (0.5") in radius (Hashimoto et al. 2012). Therefore, we propose angular resolution of 0.2" so that beam size is sufficiently smaller than the cavity size. As a result of near-IR observation, the disk extends to approximately 2" (Hashimoto et al. 2012) and thus we concidered the largest angular scale for the source is 2".

Our observation is composed of CO(J=3-2), HCO+(J=4-3), and continuum observations. Since PDS 70 a is simllar to J1604 and no HCO+(J=4-3) data is available, we applied the flux density of HCO+(J=4-3) of J1604 to PDS 70. Note that flux density of CO(J=3-2) is higher than that of HCO+(J=4-3) for low-mass pre-transitional disk and required sensitivity of HCO+(J=4-3) emission should be estimated.
As described in the technical justification in the science goal of J1604_b7_12m, the expected flux density of HCO+(J=4-3) is approximately 69 mJy/beam (CO(J=3-2) emission is 95 mJy/beam). Since we try to detect diffused gas in the cavity in this observation, we aim for 15 sigma detection. Therefore, the desired sensitivity per pointing is 4.6 mJy.
For CO(J=3-2) and HCO+(J=4-3) lines, we select velocity resolution of 0.24 km/s, corresponding to 468.75 MHz in bandwidth. Since the velocity width of this target is approximately 2.2 km/s, velocity resolution of 0.24 km/s can well resolve Keplerian motion within 100 AU.
For continuum observation, 1.875 GHz was selected for bandwidth to maximize the sensitivity. Since PDS 70 is low-mass pre transitional disk that is similar to J1604, we assume continuum peak flux of this source is comparable with that of UX Tau A, which is 17.5 mJy/beam. Our observational setup will reach the sensitivity down to approximately 0.04 mJy/beam during the line observation when total bandwidth of 3.75 GHz (1.875 GHz x 2 spw) is used. This means that it is capable of detecting a typical disk around low-mass star with tremendously high signal-to-noise ratio. As a result, the expected disk structure can be safely detected if dust exists in the cavity.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: It has become evident that protoplanetary disks have complex structures and capable of examining the inner region (a few x 10 AU) of protoplanetary disks. The Subaru Telescope has revealed that 2MASS J16042165-2130284, UX Tau A, and PDS 70 have a large cavity and, in conjunctionwith SED, have structure in their cavities, such as (proto)planet. Comparison of the appearance of the cavity/gap region at sub-millimeter wavelengths with the near-infrared data can be used to diagnose the planet mass and indeed whether the gap hosts more than one body. Our primary goal is to spatially resolve, comparable with Subaru images, and deeply observe the cavity near the mid-plane at mm/sub-mm wavelength in order to determine the size and the depth of the cavity of large dust and gas disk. We selected dust continuum, CO (J=3-2), and HCO+(J=4-3) for investigating dust and gas density structures in the large cavities. If emission inside of the cavity, which is probably influenced by planet, is detected, the companion mass can uniquely be constrained, and by augmenting the continuum measurement with gas data can constrain the location of at least the most massive bodies in the disk.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
